entity: United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia
entity_raw_name: 8.	United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia
source_file: A_80_6 (SECT. 3)_ADD.4_CLUSTER_III_FASCICLE ADVANCE UNEDITED COPY FOR ACABQ.json

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The United Nations Verification Mission in Colombia is mandated to verify five key aspects of the Final Agreement for Ending the Conflict and Building a Stable and Lasting Peace (hereinafter “the Final Agreement”), adopted in 2016 by the Government of Colombia and the former Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia – People’s Army (FARC-EP), comprising: (a) the reintegration of FARC-EP members into political, economic and social life (sect. 3.2 of the Agreement); (b) the implementation of personal and collective security and protection measures for ex-combatants, and comprehensive security and protection programmes for the communities and organizations in the territories (sect. 3.4 of the Agreement), since 2021; (c) compliance with and implementation of the restorative sentences issued by the Special Jurisdiction for Peace (sect. 5.1.2 of the Agreement); since 2023 (d) the verification of the comprehensive rural reform (sect. 1 of the Agreement); and; (e) the implementation of the ethnic chapter (sect. 6.2 of the Agreement).

Moreover, the Security Council, in its resolution 2694 (2023), expanded the Mission’s mandate to monitor and verify and the implementation of the Bilateral, National and Temporary Ceasefire Agreement between the Government of Colombia and the Ejército de Liberación Nacional (ELN).

The Mission’s mandate is defined in Security Council resolutions 2366 (2017), 2574 (2021), 2673 (2023) and 2694 (2023). By its resolution 2754 (2024), the Council renewed the mandate until 31 October 2025.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which the Mission contributes, is to advance the effective implementation of the provisions of the Final Agreement concerning reintegration, security guarantees, restorative sentences, comprehensive rural reform and the ethnic chapter, and to advance the Ceasefire Agreement.
Strategy and external factors for 2026
To contribute to the objective, the Mission will:

Apply a proactive and inclusive approach to verification, which includes advocacy, good offices, and close engagement with the parties to the Final Agreement, and relevant institutions and authorities at the international, national, regional and local levels as well as communities, women and ethnic peoples;

Conduct independent verification of the implementation of the Final Agreement, and participate, jointly with the parties, in key forums and institutions created for the implementation of the Final Agreement;

Promote constructive dialogue and trust-building between the Government and the Comunes party to address pending issues relating to peace implementation and maintain constant coordination and dialogue with key interlocutors, including actors across the political spectrum, civil society, ethnic organizations, the private sector and the international community, to foster support for the implementation of the Final Agreement;

In keeping with commitments of the Pact for the Future, particularly Action 18, provide good offices to support the implementation of the Final Agreement, monitor conflict dynamics at local levels between armed groups, support the SRSG’s role in political peace dialogues, and help build and sustain peace in Colombia.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in:

Increased trust between the parties to the Final Agreement; sustainability of the reintegration process, as well as opportunities for political participation with a specific focus on security guarantees for former combatants, social leaders and communities; progress in the implementation of key components of the comprehensive rural reform, including increased Government capacity to prevent and address land-related conflict and progress in the implementation of development plans with a territorial focus in prioritized areas, with the active participation of local communities;

Enhanced State capacity, presence and responsiveness to better prevent and investigate attacks against former combatants, social leaders and communities, as well as increased trust and understanding between the parties through tripartite coordination mechanisms, while taking into consideration the specific needs of women, children, former combatants of ethnic origin and other communities at risk;

Enhanced trust in the transitional justice system; the Government provides the conditions necessary for the Special Jurisdiction for Peace to ensure compliance with and implementation of its restorative sentences and to contribute to the realization of victims’ rights to truth, justice, reparation and non-repetition and their full inclusion in the restorative system;

Strengthened implementation of the ethnic provisions of the Final Agreement; enhanced coordination between government institutions, ethnic authorities and their organizations, including women-led organizations, and increased engagement of the international community, including the United Nations system; and
Increased trust in the peace dialogue efforts, thus contributing to a reduction in violence and improvements in the humanitarian situation in conflict-affected regions.

Regarding cooperation with other entities, the Mission engages extensively with international, national and local actors in support of its mandate. At the international level, the Mission’s close engagement with the diplomatic community and regional organisations helps to identify areas of mutual interest and support for peace consolidation. At the national and local levels, the Mission strengthens ties with political, civil society and private sector actors, including community, religious, youth, women, and ethnic leaders and persons with disabilities’ organisations, and transitional justice institutions. The Mission continues to bolster its relationships with departmental and local authorities, particularly as they gain more responsibilities regarding the reintegration process, ensuring security guarantees for communities and supporting society’s participation in the peace process.

Regarding inter-agency coordination, the Mission continues to work closely with the United Nations country team and Resident Coordinator. Through the revised United Nations Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework, the Mission and the country team developed five priorities establishing linkages between sustainable peace and the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, promoting coherence across the peace and security and the development pillars.
Regarding external factors, the plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:

Continued international support for the close engagement of the Mission and the United Nations system in the peace process. National and local authorities and relevant parties remain committed to collaborating with the Mission;
The Government and legislature will remain focused on the implementation of the Final Agreement;

National and local authorities remain engaged in increasing State presence; Authorities, State entities, and mechanisms tasked with preventing, addressing and investigating security incidents will remain committed to the prioritized populations in the Peace Agreement in conflict-affected areas;
Continued progress in judicial processes before the Special Jurisdiction for Peace, resulting in the issuance and implementation of restorative sentences; and
The Government and ELN resume the peace efforts with a view to reducing violence.

The Mission integrates a gender perspective into its activities, deliverables and results and ensures the adequate implementation of its gender parity directives and strategy. The Mission ensures that the specific needs of former FARC-EP women are fully incorporated into programme design, implementation and monitoring, particularly the security guarantees of women leaders and ex-combatants, referrals to assistance provided by Colombian authorities for victims and survivors of conflict, including from sexual and gender-based violence. The Mission fosters a gender perspective and intersectional analysis in the verification of restorative sentences, in particular concerning case 11 and others relating to sexual and gender-based violence, as well as in rural reform and the ethnic chapter, with a specific focus on the needs of peasant and ethnic women. The Mission, in line with the Pact for the Future, Action 19, provides support to the National Action Plan on Security Council resolution 1325 (2000) adopted in 2024, which is expected to strengthen the implementation of the gender provisions of the Final Agreement and reinforce the full, equal and meaningful participation of women in peacemaking.
Programme performance in 2024
Enhanced conditions for the Implementation of the Final Peace Agreement

In October 2024, the Government adopted a Rapid Response Plan to accelerate the implementation of the Final Agreement, which includes the establishment of pacts between national and local authorities to accelerate the implementation of the Development Programmes with a Territorial Focus (PDET) and to enhance their transformative potential in conflict-affected regions; as well as actions related to the comprehensive rural reform and security guarantees, among others. The Mission, through the good offices of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General and the technical teams, accompanied the Government in the formulation of the plan, including identifying key territorial priorities to be included in the pacts between national and local authorities. The Plan underlined the execution of development and infrastructure projects in key regions for the Peace Agreement, thus mobilising resources and engaging relevant local actors to accelerate the implementation of the Final Agreement.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 43)
Table 43
Performance measure –

Rapid Response Plan launched nationally to accelerate the implementation of the Peace Agreement.

children.text: Planned results for 2026
Result 1: progress in the effective implementation of comprehensive rural reform and ethnic chapters – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission focused on institutional coordination and consensus-building for the implementation of the rural reform and ethnic chapter, leading to agreements to boost the implementation of ethnic chapter in the Department of Chocó, timely land distribution and the delivery of productive assets to relevant actors.

In 2026, the Mission will take stock of the Government's goals and promote continuity of strategies and policies related to the implementation of the comprehensive rural reform and ethnic chapter. Efforts will aim at advancing the comprehensive rural reform at the local and departmental levels and fulfilling the commitments outlined in the ethnic chapter.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 44).
Table 44 – Performance measure

2023 (actual)
2024 (actual)
2025 (planned)
2026 (planned)

Security guarantees, verification guidelines and risk analysis developed in support of the rural reform and ethnic chapter
Verification of delivery of land to peasants and ethnic groups, with the Government formalizing the acquisition and transfer of tenure
Progress made in the planning of the development programme with a territorial focus for a comprehensive and high-impact approach, with civil society participation
Implementation of a coordination mechanism between all relevant
Establishment of priorities and targets for through the signing of the pact for the implementation of the ethnic chapter

Significant progress in formalizing land tenure, reaching 5.7 per cent and land adjudication on 43.8 per cent, according to official figures.
Finalized the consultation and prioritisation phase of the 16 PDET, along with progress in designing a funding plan for strategic projects and territorial pacts established under the Rapid Response Plan.
Enhanced collaboration with the National Commission of Indigenous Territories, incorporating territorial aspects of the ethnic chapter related to Comprehensive Rural Reform. 
Ethnic chapter provisions incorporated in key public policies: the demining strategy, victim reparations, and land restitution for ethnic peoples, prioritised.

Implementation of development programmes with a territorial focus is accelerated
Increase in the delivery of land to rural reform beneficiaries, including ethnic groups, as well as goods and services, ensuring land productivity 
Strengthened institutions in charge of implementing the ethnic chapter
Enhanced collaboration between government entities implementing the ethnic chapter and Afro-Colombian and Indigenous leaders and their organizations, private sector and other stakeholders
Progress in the targets set in the pact for the implementation of the ethnic chapter is on track

Progress in land delivery and rural development goals, the multipurpose land registry, the effective operation of the agrarian jurisdiction, and the implementation of PDETs, consolidation of the National Agrarian Reform System and associated coordination mechanisms
Progress in the implementation of updated PDET plans
Advances in the implementation of the Ethnic Chapter based on the Pact commitments
Departmental Governments incorporated the provisions of the Ethnic Chapter into their public policies and developed roadmaps for departmental implementation

children.text: Result 2: strengthened security conditions for communities in conflict-affected areas through advances in the implementation of the Final Agreement and effective implementation of the Ceasefire Agreement between the Government and the Ejército de Liberación Nacional – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

In 2024, the Mission was instrumental to advancing security and protection measures for former combatants and communities, including the adoption of the public policy for dismantling illegal armed groups and criminal organizations and strengthening the framework of the strategic security and protection plan. The Mission, through the Monitoring and Verification Mechanism of the Ceasefire Agreement, contributed to violence reduction, while closely monitoring local conflict dynamics. Although the parties did not renew the Ceasefire Agreement, they met twice in efforts to overcome obstacles to a possible resumption of the ceasefire.

In 2026, the Mission will continue to advance prevention and protection policies, analyse conflict dynamics. The Special Representative of the Secretary-General will continue his good offices role in peace dialogues.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 45).
Table 45 – Performance measure

Prevented confrontations between the parties and supported the de-escalation of violence in the regions: four fatalities among ELN members and security forces recorded during the ceasefire (Aug. 2023 – Aug. 2024)
Enhanced policies and plans on security guarantees for former combatants and affected communities:  approval of the public policy on dismantling of criminal organizations and armed groups; implementation of the emergency evacuation and extraction protocol and strengthening of the Special Investigations Unit.

Progress in the implementation of the Ceasefire Agreement between the Government and ELN
Ceasefire agreements and protocols are enhanced, including through technical support provided by the Mission within its participation in the Monitoring and Verification Mechanism
Reduction in violent clashes between public forces and illegal armed groups
Improved security conditions for communities in conflict-affected areas as a result of the ceasefire

Implementation of the public policy on dismantling of criminal organizations and armed groups in two pilot areas, acceleration of its implementation in the other 11 prioritized areas
Implemented prevention and protection mechanisms and policies 
Reduced violence, through increased access to programmes for former combatants, leaders and organizations in rural areas 
Reduced violence between armed groups and public forces; improved security in conflict-affected areas.
Enhanced trust between the parties to the peace dialogues.

children.text: Result 3: Effective implementation of restorative sentences for the restoration of victims’ rights and legal certainty for those under Special Jurisdiction for Peace – Proposed programme plan for 2026

In 2025, the Mission anticipates the issuance of the first restorative sentences by the Peace Tribunal of the Special Jurisdiction for Peace cases 1 and 3, the first since the signing of the Final Agreement. The Mission has engaged with relevant entities, fine-tuning methodology and strengthening the monitoring and verification mechanism and information-sharing mechanisms. The Mission engaged with institutions responsible for ensuring that conditions for the implementation of the restorative sentences are fulfilled.
Lessons learned and planned changes

Despite advances, there has been limited progress towards the issuance of restorative sentences, with four cases in trial phase. To help remedy the situation, the Mission will increase its advocacy and good offices with relevant entities, disseminating information on the transitional justice system to build trust between the parties and communities, including through the Monitoring and Verification Mechanism of restorative sentences established with the Special Jurisdiction for Peace.
Progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 46)
Table 46 – Performance measure

C.	Substantive deliverables

Good offices: parties advance implementation of the Final Agreement, including gender provisions; advocacy for increased dialogue between relevant stakeholders; visits from key stakeholders to reintegration areas where former combatants are developing productive projects and community-based initiatives, including reinforcing the role of the technical working group on gender within the National Reintegration Council; implementation of the women, peace and security agenda as part of the implementation of the Final Agreement, including advancing women’s participation; support peace dialogues, to facilitate communication between parties and support the implementation of relevant agreements; increased participation of society in peace efforts.

Digital platforms and multimedia content: social media channels and United Nations information platforms to create and disseminate information on the Mission’s mandate. Reach at least 145,500 followers on X; 78,200 followers on Facebook and 34,700 on Instagram. Implementation of strategies to address misinformation, disinformation and hate speech for early warning and response (Socialization workshops on the United Nations Global Strategy).

children.text: a	Other level, unless otherwise stated.

The proposed resource requirements for 2026 for the Mission amount to $86,953,100 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for the deployment of 188 military observers ($6,480,800), salaries and common staff costs ($47,383,800) for 181 international posts (1 Under-Secretary-General, 1 Assistant Secretary-General, 6 D-1, 26 P-5, 38 P-4, 58 P-3, 2 P-2 and 49 Field Service), 218 national posts (113 National Professional Officer, 1 General Service and 104 Local level) and 183 United Nations Volunteers (153 international and 30 national), and operational costs ($33,088,500), comprising the costs for consultants and consulting services ($458,800), official travel ($2,106,200), facilities and infrastructure ($8,144,900), ground transportation ($2,274,100), air operations ($12,116,300), marine operations ($462,000), communications and information technology ($5,084,400), medical ($427,800) and other supplies, services and equipment ($2,014,000).
A vacancy rate of 7.5 per cent has been applied to military observers based on the actual average vacancy rate during 2024.

A vacancy rate of 18.8 per cent has been applied to the estimates for international staff and 30.1 per cent for National Professional Officers based on the actual vacancy rate in March 2025; 28.1 per cent for the Local level categories staff based on the actual average vacancy rate in 2024. Vacancy rates of 5.0 per cent and 7.0 per cent have been applied to international and national United Nations Volunteers, respectively, based on the actual vacancy rates in March 2025. A vacancy rate of 50 per cent has been applied to the estimates for the posts proposed for reassignment.

To ensure effective mandate delivery, a number of changes to the organizational and staffing structure are proposed for 2026, including the redeployment of three posts to increase conflict analysis capacities in key Offices as the fragmentation of armed groups, the increasingly localized conflicts and threats to former combatants that could impact the implementation of the Final Agreement; as well the reassignment of two posts, as detailed below:
Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General

Redeployment of one post of Assistant Public Information Officer (National Professional Officer), from the Information Management Unit under the Office of the Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General, to the Strategic Communications and Public Information Unit within the Office of the Special Representative of the Secretary-General, to assist in promoting public awareness on the Mission mandate and the peace process. Efforts are needed to enhance strategic communication and reach a larger audience with consistent and balanced information, as well as raise awareness about the Peace Agreement, in particular in anticipation of the first restorative sentences by the Special Jurisdiction for Peace Tribunal, expected in 2026. The incumbent will assist in producing critical graphic and communication materials nationwide and awareness-raising campaigns boosting trust in the transitional justice system.
Office of the Verification of Security Guarantees

Redeployment of one long-vacant post of Liaison Officer (National Professional Officer) from the Regional Office of Florencia to the Office of the Verification of Security Guarantees within the same Office of the Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General in Bogota. The Liaison Officer will analyse evolving conditions nationwide, including threats, actors and dynamics, for expanded conflict analysis and assessment of potential impact to former combatants and victims of the conflict for preventative recommendations, preparedness, advocacy, and engagement at the national level.
Office of the Chief of Staff

Redeployment of one long vacant post of Liaison Officer (National Professional Officer) from the Regional Office of Villavicencio to the Office of the Chief of Staff in Bogota to improve information gathering situational awareness and analysis for strategic recommendations to the SRSG and Mission leadership.
Transport Unit

Reassignment of one vacant post of Field Security Assistant (Local level) from the Security Section’s presence in Arauca to the Transport Unit as a Driver (Local level) to provide dedicated capacity to the Deputy Special Representative of the Secretary-General;
Financial Resourcing, Performance and Risk Management Unit

Reassignment of one post of Field Security Assistant (Local level) from the Regional Security Section’s presence in Ocaña to the Financial Resourcing, Performance and Risk Management Unit in Bogota as a Finance and Budget Assistant (Local level) to contribute to better informed decision-making. This will ensure robust financial management and operational efficiency especially while the Mission is experiencing liquidity constraints and needs to implement additional management measures.

The increase in requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable mainly to: (a) increased requirements for military observers due to the increase in the mission subsistence allowance rates (higher actual daily rate of the "after 30 days" mission subsistence allowances of $94 effective 1 January 2025 compared with the rate of $63 applied in the approved budget for 2025) as well as application of a lower vacancy rate of 7.5 per cent compared to 10.1 per cent in 2025 budget; (b) additional requirements for international United Nations Volunteers due to increased monthly living allowance; (c) increased requirements for air operations due to a change in contractual arrangements, which increased guaranteed fleet costs, and to additional flight hours for fixed-wing and rotary-wing aircraft and related requirements for aviation fuel necessary to support mandate implementation in the locations outside Bogota and ensure connectivity between locations; and (d) increased requirements for marine operations to support additional riverine activities to cover an enlarged mission area especially the locations that are not accessible by ground nor air transportation. The increased requirements are offset in part by: (a) reduced requirements for international staff owing to lower estimated common staff costs (estimated common staff costs as a percentage of salary costs of 51.7 per cent compared to 56.8 per cent in the 2025 budget); (b) reduced requirements for national staff owing to the application of higher vacancy rates for National Professional Officers and Local level staff; (c) reduced requirements for consultants owing to the higher reliance on in-house expertise; (d) reduced requirements under facilities and infrastructure owing to lower estimated costs for the rental of premises and non-acquisition of furniture; (e) lower estimated costs for rental of vehicles owing to efficiencies gained through the full transfer of rental of vehicles to the United Nations fleet modality; (f) fewer acquisition of communication and information technology equipment; (g) lower requirements for medical services; (h) lower requirements for freight due to fewer acquisition; and (i) lower requirements under other services, owing to a planned reduction in meeting facilitation, as a cost avoidance measure.
